alignments.title: Humorous Approach
alignments.description: The current video takes a humorous and satirical approach to making carbonara, which is not present in the previous video. It includes jokes about using bacon instead of guanciale, and humorous commentary on the process, such as the idea of using a drill to grate cheese or the notion of breaking spaghetti being a crime in Italy. This comedic style is a new element compared to the straightforward instructional style of the previous video.
new_quotes: Fai schifo cucinare, ja totalmente schifo!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.

alignments.title: Non-traditional Elements
alignments.description: The current video explicitly states that it is not making traditional carbonara, which is a new context compared to the previous video that focuses on making a traditional version. The current video plays with the idea of what makes a dish carbonara, humorously suggesting that adding peas or cream would disqualify it as carbonara.
new_quotes: Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
prev_quotes: You need to understand, carbonara does not need cream, or peas, or ham, or whatever else people are putting in it.
Traditionally, you're gonna see spaghetti carbonara made with guanciale, which is the jowl, meaning the cheek of a pig that's been cured.

alignments.title: Egg Yolk Technique

new_quotes: Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
prev_quotes: A lot of recipes call for all whole, all yolks. I like to do a mixture of both. So I'm doing three whole eggs, as well as two egg yolks.

alignments.title: Pasta Water Rationale

new_quotes: The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
prev_quotes: And if it looks too thick to you, also what you can do is just add a little bit of that pasta water. That's going to loosen it up.

new_quotes: In this case, it's sort of spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti.

alignments.title: No Oil in Water
alignments.description: The current video advises against adding oil to the pasta water, which is not mentioned in the previous video. This is new as it clarifies a common misconception about cooking pasta and ensures the sauce adheres better to the pasta.
new_quotes: While this is cooking, it takes good 10 minutes, and no oil, please. No oil, because you don't need it.

alignments.title: Guanciale Explanation
alignments.description: The current video provides a detailed explanation of guanciale, its origin, and its preparation, which is not present in the previous video. This is new as it educates the viewer on the traditional ingredient used in Carbonara.
new_quotes: Now, for the original Carbonara, you need the guanciale, which is the cheek, the pork cheek. And the Romans, they're very special in that because they do it, they cure it like ham, or like pancetta, and it's very tender, very tasty and tender.

alignments.title: Egg Yolk Only
alignments.description: The current video specifies using only egg yolks for the sauce, which is a traditional method not explicitly detailed in the previous video. This is new as it emphasizes the authenticity of the recipe.
new_quotes: To be a little bit naughty, I take just the yolk, and we beat it.

alignments.title: No Cream Allowed
alignments.description: The current video explicitly states that no cream should be added to the Carbonara, which is a common mistake not addressed in the previous video. This is new as it reinforces the traditional method of making Carbonara.
new_quotes: To this, you don't add any, any, any cream. Absolutely forbidden.

alignments.title: Fat Removal Trick
alignments.description: The current video shows a trick to remove excess fat from the guanciale, which is not mentioned in the previous video. This is new as it provides a method to adjust the dish's richness according to personal preference.
new_quotes: Should you be not wanting the fat, I show you a little trick. Here we are. And do this. You absorb a little bit of the fat, and you take it off like this.

alignments.title: Cooling Pasta Technique
alignments.description: The current video describes a technique to cool the pasta slightly before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling, which is not mentioned in the previous video. This is new as it ensures the sauce remains creamy and smooth.
new_quotes: You let it cool down in doing this. And it shouldn't be too hot because what is going to happen now should be the temperature enough to coat the egg around the pasta.

alignments.title: Final Embellishment
